abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Microbes that protect against infection inhabit hosts across the tree of life. It is unclear whether and how the host immune system may affect the formation of new protective symbioses. We investigated the transcriptomic response of<jats:italic>Caenorhabditis elegans</jats:italic>following novel interactions with a protective microbe (<jats:italic>Enterococcus faecalis</jats:italic>) able to defend against infection by pathogenic<jats:italic>Staphylococcus aureus</jats:italic>. We have previously shown that<jats:italic>E. faecalis</jats:italic>can directly limit pathogen growth within hosts. In this study, we show that colonisation by protective<jats:italic>E. faecalis</jats:italic>caused the differential expression of 1,557 genes in pathogen infected hosts, including the upregulation of immune genes such as lysozymes and C-type lectins. The most significantly upregulated host lysozyme gene,<jats:italic>lys-7,</jats:italic>impacted the competitive abilities of<jats:italic>E. faecalis</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>S. aureus</jats:italic>when knocked out.<jats:italic>E. faecalis</jats:italic>has an increased ability to resist lysozyme activity compared to<jats:italic>S. aureus</jats:italic>, suggesting that the protective microbe could gain a competitive advantage from this host response. Our finding that protective microbes can benefit from immune-mediated competition after introduction opens up new possibilities for biocontrol design and our understanding of symbiosis evolution. Crosstalk between the host immune response and microbe-mediated protection should favour the continued investment in host immunity and avoid the potentially risky evolution of host dependence.</jats:p>
